title.title: Mayor confirms £4.2m for local transport improvements in Hillingdon

texts: Greater freedom for Hillingdon over local transport spending delivers innovative transport projects.
Even in these tough economic times I am committed to providing this funding to all of London's boroughs
The Mayor of London today confirmed £4.2m for Hillingdon to spend on local transport improvements during 2010/11, including £635,000 for essential road maintenance and £200,000 for major schemes.
Hillingdon has been developing proposals for a number of schemes that it will be financing with the funding package, including:

{"template":"bulletlist","items":["£190,000 to develop pedestrian crossings on key school travel routes including routes to Hillingdon, Pinkwell, Frithwood \u0026 Oak Farm Primary Schools","£100,000 to improve footpaths and pedestrian crossing on the edge of Uxbridge Town Centre","£93,000 to repair infrared low bridge detectors at South Ruislip Station Bridge to encourage freight vehicles to use main corridors and avoid residential roads"]}
Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, said: 'Even in these tough economic times I am committed to providing this funding to all of London's boroughs.
'The investment means that across the Capital, town centres and public spaces are being overhauled, cycling and walking facilities are being improved, and roads are being made safer.

'We have cut red tape to make it easier for borough councils to choose the local transport projects that benefit their residents the most, simplifying the funding system and working together to give local people the improvements they want.
Funding for local schemes is allocated each year by Transport for London (TfL).
The Mayor has simplified the system - reducing the number of funding streams from 23 to five, and introducing fairer funding formulas where needed.

London's Transport Commissioner, Peter Hendy, said: 'Hillingdon has identified a range of small and large scale projects that will make a real difference to local people by improving town centres and public spaces, reducing the number of collisions on our roads, improving the environment and promoting greener forms of travel.
'Hillingdon also has the flexibility to move certain funding between projects if, during the course of the year, they find more or less funding is needed for individual schemes.'
